rows: A leaf arrangement in which leaves are arranged singly, one leaf per nod, alternating on either side of the stem
The length of twig between two sets of bud scale scars, or between the terminal bud and a set of bud scale scars
Appendages (e.g. leaves and bracts) are produced along axes, and grow to a fixed size and shape, in characteristic patterns of arrangement
Axes are the trunks of trees, individual stems, branches, or twigs, all of which typically continue to grow in length from a bud at the tip
The position in the angle formed between the stem and the upper side of the leaf stalk
Buds found in the axil of a leaf
A modified of specialized leaf associated with a reproductive structure such as a flower, inflorescence, or cone scale
An adjective describing plants having bracts
Scale-like modified leaves that protect the lateral and terminal buds
Scars surrounding the twig, which are left by the previous year's terminal bud
Smaller markings within a leaf scar left by vascular bundle connections between the leaf and the twig
The upper leafy portion of a tree
An adjective describing plants lacking bracts
A modified shoot often arising from axils, consisting of an axis that bears specialized appendages (e.g. sepals, petals, stamens, and pistils)
The pairs of leaves on the upper and lower surfaces in a flattened foliage spray
A fern-like growth of 2-ranked branchlets composed of pairs of overlapping scale leaves. When foliage is in flattened sprays, the scale leaves are arranged in overlapping pairs on 4 sides
An adjective describing leaves that have a distinct, sharp angled edge fold along the midrib or in the bottom, resembling the keel of a boat
The pairs of leaves at right angles on either side of the facial pair in a flattened foliage spray
The mark on a twig left by the shedding of a leaf, indicating where the previous year's leaf stalk was attached
One of many raised pores in the stem of a woody plant that enable gas exchange between the atmosphere and the twig
Main shoots that elongate between the nodes, becoming branches and trunks that contribute to the woody framework of a tree
A narrow, pointed leaf that may be borne in bundles or singly. Bundles are inserted above a non-photosynthetic scale leaf
The position of the needle relative to the branch. Needles may be curved or straight. They may lie in a flat plane, be angled upward, or project at right angles to the stem
Leaves that form on long shoots during the growing season
The site of leaf attachment, an axillary bud, and potentially a lateral branch
A leaf arrangement in which leaves are arranged in pairs, opposite to one another at the same node
A core of tissue inside the twig that is usually solid and continuous, but can be chambered, sectioned, or spongy
The male, pollen-producing reproductive structure in conifers
Leaves formed within a bud from the previous season
Sharp outgrowths or projections from the epidermis of a plant structure
A winged nut or achene containing one seed
The female, seed-producing reproductive structure in conifers. Seed cones have a central axis covered with bracts nestling seed scales
Single or multiple structures axillary to a bract, protecting a seed
Leaves with little or no expanded blade portion. Scales may have a gland or be keeled on the outer face
A leaf arrangement in which leaves rotate around the stem, not in the same plane
A needle base modified into a woody peg
A small leaf-like appendage to a leaf, typically borne in pairs at the base of the leaf stalk
The mark left by the stipule attached to the previous year's growth
Lines of stomates arranged on either side of the midrib that appear as yellow or white stripes on the underside or upper surface of the needle
The breathing pores in the epidermis of all leaves that are used to exchange gases and reduce water loss
Shoots that grow from year to year with little internodal elongation between the annual batches of closely spaced leaves
The bud enclosing the growing point of a shoot and its side branches
Short shoots that have been modified to have a hard, sharp point, and which may be simple or compound
The main stem of a tree, which supports the branches and connects to the roots underground - the main axis from which subsidiary branches arise
A leaf arrangement in which each node bears three or more leaves
